¶ Seint Austin brou&yogh;te cristindom &punctelev; þus into Enguelonde
Wel au&yogh;te we his [dai] Anouri &punctelev; &yogh;if we weren wel vnderstonde
¶ His day is toward þe ende of May &punctelev; for in þat day he wende
Out of þis lijf to ihesu crist &punctelev; þat after him þo sende
Bidde we &yogh;eorne seint Austin &punctelev; þat cristindom so brou&yogh;te
Þat we moten to þulke Ioye come &punctelev; to &yogh;wan ore louerd us bou&yogh;te
SEint Barnabe þe Apostle &punctelev; þat guod was and hiende
I-Martred he was for godes loue &punctelev; in strongue deþe atþenende
After þat ore swete louerd &punctelev; to heouene gan i-wende
Þe Apostles precheden cristindom &punctelev; ase he heom gan wit siende
¶ Seint Barnabe i-sai&yogh; þo &punctelev; þat his bi-leue nas nou&yogh;t
he turnde sone to þe Apostles &punctelev; and to ore louerd al is þou&yogh;t
Of lond he hadde ane grete feld &punctelev; and he it solde wel faste
to þe Apostles he wende anon &punctelev; and to heore fet þe panes caste
And for-sok al þis world[r. worldes] guod &punctelev; and heore felawe bi-cam
And I-martred he was with heom &punctelev; for loue of cristindam
Sethþe þo seint powel &punctelev; to þe Apostles wende
Þe Apostles ne lefden it nou&yogh;t &punctelev; þat ore louerd him to heom sende
Ake wenden þat he a gylur were &punctelev; so þat hit was longue
For he hadde so luþur man i-be— &punctelev; are huy dorsten him vnder|fongue
¶ Seint Barnabe i-knev him ferst &punctelev; so þat he formest brou&yogh;te
Þe apostles in cuthrade with him &punctelev; and in ri&yogh;te þou&yogh;te
And tolde heom hov ore swete louerd &punctelev; bi weye to him cam
And smot him and bi-nam him is si&yogh;t &punctelev; and brou&yogh;te him to cristindom
¶ Sethþe þo fram Ierusalem &punctelev; þe Apostles gonne wende
For-to prechi godes lawe &punctelev; þat so guod is and hende
And to þe londe of Cypre &punctelev; seint Barnabe huy gonne þo sende:[This v. om. in other MSS.]
Ase he wende forth in is wei &punctelev; in one stude he fond
A felau&yogh;schipe of quoynte Men &punctelev; þe wiseste of al þe lond
he spac with heom so quoynteliche &punctelev; ase he bi heom cam
Þat þar nas non of heom alle &punctelev; þat ne wondrede of his wisdam
"Sire sire," seide on of heom &punctelev; þat was of grete fame
"Tel us of &yogh;wannes þou art &punctelev; and &yogh;wat is þi name
And fram &yogh;wannes þou art hidere i-come &punctelev; and for &yogh;wuche þingue;
Þou comest here into ore lond &punctelev; ich wot for sume tiþingue."
¶ Seint Barnabe þis holie Man &punctelev; fondede in eche pointe
to answerien heom wel quoynteliche &punctelev; for huy weren heom-self so quoynte
"Sire," he seide, "þov axest wel &punctelev; and ich ou wulle telle
Barnabe ich am i-cleoped &punctelev; þe deueles fo of helle
Iesu cristes man ich am &punctelev; þat me gan hidere siende
Fram Ierusalem ich am i-come &punctelev; and þus a-boute wiende
For-to prechi is holie name &punctelev; þat brou&yogh;te us out of biende
Bi-leueth on him and &yogh;e worþeth in Ioye &punctelev; euere with-oute ende."
he prechede so þis grete men &punctelev; þat huy turnden heore þou&yogh;t
And weren þare to cristindom &punctelev; þoru&yogh; seint Barnabe i-brou&yogh;t
And bi-liefden on Iesu crist &punctelev; and heore heorte ope him caste
And prechede also of ihesu crist &punctelev; and turnde þut folk wel faste
Seint Barnabe wende him forth &punctelev; and to þe londe of cipre he com
to tuyrne men to ihesu crist &punctelev; and to prechi cristindom
He cam and fond a foul dede &punctelev; þat schendful was to do
Men vrne nakede al a-boute &punctelev; and wummen al-so
Seint Barnabe was þar-of a-schamed &punctelev; for it was a schenful dede
Þat þe schrewene neren a-schamede nou&yogh;t &punctelev; to schewi heore wrechhede
To þe temple he wende a-non &punctelev; ope &yogh;wan huy a-vouweden heore schame
And a-mansede þat sori temple &punctelev; in ore louerdes name
A-non with þis mansingue &punctelev; al þat on half dachste a-dovnn
Þoru&yogh; grete wreche of þis temple &punctelev; with gret noyse and soun
Þo þe schrewes i-sei&yogh;en þe wreche &punctelev; þat so schamelese were
huy bi-lefden þulke schendfole dede &punctelev; huy ne dorsten non-oþur for fere
þis holie man wende him forth &punctelev; ferrore in þe lond :[MS. londe]
Tymon, þat was an holi man &punctelev; in a stude he fond
Þat in a strong acces was of a feuere &punctelev; and al atþe deþe nei&yogh;
Seint Barnabe of-þou&yogh;te it sore &punctelev; þo he him i-sei&yogh;
Þe godspelles of seint Mathev &punctelev; with him euere he ber
In a bok; ase god it wolde &punctelev; with him he hadde as þer
Þis bok he leide ope þis man &punctelev; ase he so sijk þer lay
he bi-cam anon hol and sound &punctelev; ase al þat folk i-say,[MS. i isay]
And wende forth with him a-boute &punctelev; hol and glad i-nov&yogh;
And prechede &yogh;eorne of ihesu crist &punctelev; and folk fram sunne drov&yogh;
Of ore swete louerd of heouene &punctelev; seint Barnabe hadde swich grace
Þat, &yogh;if he founde ani sijk man &punctelev; ase he wende in ani place
And he leide ope him þis bok &punctelev; þat so holi and guod was
Of þe godspelles of seint Mathev &punctelev; so strong siknesse non nas
Þat he þoru&yogh; ore louerdes grace &punctelev; ne helde þar-of a-non;
Þare-þoru&yogh; he maude mani men &punctelev; to Iesu criste gon
Þoru&yogh; vertue of þis holie Man &punctelev; and of þis holie bok al-so
Muche fair mi&yogh;thte ore louerd hath &punctelev; in his seriaunz ido
Þis holie man seint Barnabe &punctelev; &yogh;et forþere he wende
And prechede þe giwes faste &punctelev; hore lijf for-to amende
Manie he tornede to cristindom &punctelev; and þene holi gost on heom tende
Þoru&yogh; miracles þat he dude &punctelev; and þoru&yogh; grace þat god him sende
¶ Bareu was a luþur giv &punctelev; þat euere weorrede faste
Seint powel and seint Barnabe &punctelev; and cudde it at þe laste
For þo he fond seint Barnabe &punctelev; þat folk to ore louerd so wiende
To þe luþere Iustise of þe lond &punctelev; þe tiþingue he gan siende
Þis holi man was sone i-nome &punctelev; and to dome i-brou&yogh;t
huy tormenteden him harde and stronge &punctelev; forto torni is þou&yogh;t
Alle manere turmenz huy him duden &punctelev; þat huy mi&yogh;thten on bi-þenche
huy ne mi&yogh;thten him nou&yogh;t &yogh;eot enes make &punctelev; fram god is þou&yogh;t blenche
¶ Ase huy weren with al heore mi&yogh;te &punctelev; a-boute him[al. om.] faste and longue
For-to defouli þis holie man &punctelev; with tormenz harde and strongue
¶ Þe Aumperores o cosin &punctelev; þat of gret power was
In-to toune cam þulke time &punctelev; ase it feol bi cas
Þe giwes weren so sore a-drad &punctelev; laste he hem bi-nome
Þoru&yogh; strencþe seint Barnabe &punctelev; and ladde him to rome
A-ni&yogh;ht huy nomen þis holie man &punctelev; ase he was to-raunsed so
And teiden ane rop a-boute is necke &punctelev; and knutten him faste þerto
And drowen him out of heore synagoge &punctelev; with seoruwe and pine i-nov&yogh;
And sethþe al-so bi þe sweore &punctelev; out atþe &yogh;ate men him drov&yogh;
And mauden a-boute him swiþe gret fuyr &punctelev; and barnden him al-to nou&yogh;te
his soule wende to þe Ioye of heouene &punctelev; þat he wel deore a-bou&yogh;te
¶ Þo nomen þe luþere men heore red &punctelev; &yogh;wanne huy mi&yogh;ten atþe laste
his bones þat weren bi-left vn-barnd &punctelev; a-midde þe .se. to caste
Ake cristine Men þat weren bi-side &punctelev; stelen to bi ni&yogh;te
And bureden as wel stilleliche &punctelev; with ase gret honour ase huy mi&yogh;te
Nov bidde we &yogh;eorne ihesu crist &punctelev; king of alle kinge
For loue of seint Barnabe &punctelev; þat he us to heouene bringue
SEint Barnabe þe Apostle &punctelev; þat guod was and hiende
I-Martred he was for godes loue &punctelev; in strongue deþe atþenende
After þat ore swete louerd &punctelev; to heouene gan i-wende
Þe Apostles precheden cristindom &punctelev; ase he heom gan wit siende
¶ Seint Barnabe i-sai&yogh; þo &punctelev; þat his bi-leue nas nou&yogh;t
he turnde sone to þe Apostles &punctelev; and to ore louerd al is þou&yogh;t
Of lond he hadde ane grete feld &punctelev; and he it solde wel faste
to þe Apostles he wende anon &punctelev; and to heore fet þe panes caste
And for-sok al þis world[r. worldes] guod &punctelev; and heore felawe bi-cam
And I-martred he was with heom &punctelev; for loue of cristindam
Sethþe þo seint powel &punctelev; to þe Apostles wende
Þe Apostles ne lefden it nou&yogh;t &punctelev; þat ore louerd him to heom sende
Ake wenden þat he a gylur were &punctelev; so þat hit was longue
For he hadde so luþur man i-be— &punctelev; are huy dorsten him vnder|fongue
¶ Seint Barnabe i-knev him ferst &punctelev; so þat he formest brou&yogh;te
Þe apostles in cuthrade with him &punctelev; and in ri&yogh;te þou&yogh;te
And tolde heom hov ore swete louerd &punctelev; bi weye to him cam
And smot him and bi-nam him is si&yogh;t &punctelev; and brou&yogh;te him to cristindom
¶ Sethþe þo fram Ierusalem &punctelev; þe Apostles gonne wende
For-to prechi godes lawe &punctelev; þat so guod is and hende
And to þe londe of Cypre &punctelev; seint Barnabe huy gonne þo sende:[This v. om. in other MSS.]
Ase he wende forth in is wei &punctelev; in one stude he fond
A felau&yogh;schipe of quoynte Men &punctelev; þe wiseste of al þe lond
he spac with heom so quoynteliche &punctelev; ase he bi heom cam
Þat þar nas non of heom alle &punctelev; þat ne wondrede of his wisdam
"Sire sire," seide on of heom &punctelev; þat was of grete fame
"Tel us of &yogh;wannes þou art &punctelev; and &yogh;wat is þi name
And fram &yogh;wannes þou art hidere i-come &punctelev; and for &yogh;wuche þingue;
Þou comest here into ore lond &punctelev; ich wot for sume tiþingue."
¶ Seint Barnabe þis holie Man &punctelev; fondede in eche pointe
to answerien heom wel quoynteliche &punctelev; for huy weren heom-self so quoynte
"Sire," he seide, "þov axest wel &punctelev; and ich ou wulle telle
Barnabe ich am i-cleoped &punctelev; þe deueles fo of helle
Iesu cristes man ich am &punctelev; þat me gan hidere siende
Fram Ierusalem ich am i-come &punctelev; and þus a-boute wiende
For-to prechi is holie name &punctelev; þat brou&yogh;te us out of biende
Bi-leueth on him and &yogh;e worþeth in Ioye &punctelev; euere with-oute ende."
he prechede so þis grete men &punctelev; þat huy turnden heore þou&yogh;t
And weren þare to cristindom &punctelev; þoru&yogh; seint Barnabe i-brou&yogh;t
And bi-liefden on Iesu crist &punctelev; and heore heorte ope him caste
And prechede also of ihesu crist &punctelev; and turnde þut folk wel faste
Seint Barnabe wende him forth &punctelev; and to þe londe of cipre he com
to tuyrne men to ihesu crist &punctelev; and to prechi cristindom
He cam and fond a foul dede &punctelev; þat schendful was to do
Men vrne nakede al a-boute &punctelev; and wummen al-so
Seint Barnabe was þar-of a-schamed &punctelev; for it was a schenful dede
Þat þe schrewene neren a-schamede nou&yogh;t &punctelev; to schewi heore wrechhede
To þe temple he wende a-non &punctelev; ope &yogh;wan huy a-vouweden heore schame
And a-mansede þat sori temple &punctelev; in ore louerdes name
A-non with þis mansingue &punctelev; al þat on half dachste a-dovnn
Þoru&yogh; grete wreche of þis temple &punctelev; with gret noyse and soun
Þo þe schrewes i-sei&yogh;en þe wreche &punctelev; þat so schamelese were
huy bi-lefden þulke schendfole dede &punctelev; huy ne dorsten non-oþur for fere
þis holie man wende him forth &punctelev; ferrore in þe lond :[MS. londe]
Tymon, þat was an holi man &punctelev; in a stude he fond
Þat in a strong acces was of a feuere &punctelev; and al atþe deþe nei&yogh;
Seint Barnabe of-þou&yogh;te it sore &punctelev; þo he him i-sei&yogh;
Þe godspelles of seint Mathev &punctelev; with him euere he ber
In a bok; ase god it wolde &punctelev; with him he hadde as þer
Þis bok he leide ope þis man &punctelev; ase he so sijk þer lay
he bi-cam anon hol and sound &punctelev; ase al þat folk i-say,[MS. i isay]
And wende forth with him a-boute &punctelev; hol and glad i-nov&yogh;
And prechede &yogh;eorne of ihesu crist &punctelev; and folk fram sunne drov&yogh;
Of ore swete louerd of heouene &punctelev; seint Barnabe hadde swich grace
Þat, &yogh;if he founde ani sijk man &punctelev; ase he wende in ani place
And he leide ope him þis bok &punctelev; þat so holi and guod was
Of þe godspelles of seint Mathev &punctelev; so strong siknesse non nas
Þat he þoru&yogh; ore louerdes grace &punctelev; ne helde þar-of a-non;
Þare-þoru&yogh; he maude mani men &punctelev; to Iesu criste gon
Þoru&yogh; vertue of þis holie Man &punctelev; and of þis holie bok al-so
Muche fair mi&yogh;thte ore louerd hath &punctelev; in his seriaunz ido
Þis holie man seint Barnabe &punctelev; &yogh;et forþere he wende
And prechede þe giwes faste &punctelev; hore lijf for-to amende
Manie he tornede to cristindom &punctelev; and þene holi gost on heom tende
Þoru&yogh; miracles þat he dude &punctelev; and þoru&yogh; grace þat god him sende
¶ Bareu was a luþur giv &punctelev; þat euere weorrede faste
Seint powel and seint Barnabe &punctelev; and cudde it at þe laste
For þo he fond seint Barnabe &punctelev; þat folk to ore louerd so wiende
To þe luþere Iustise of þe lond &punctelev; þe tiþingue he gan siende
Þis holi man was sone i-nome &punctelev; and to dome i-brou&yogh;t
huy tormenteden him harde and stronge &punctelev; forto torni is þou&yogh;t
Alle manere turmenz huy him duden &punctelev; þat huy mi&yogh;thten on bi-þenche
huy ne mi&yogh;thten him nou&yogh;t &yogh;eot enes make &punctelev; fram god is þou&yogh;t blenche
¶ Ase huy weren with al heore mi&yogh;te &punctelev; a-boute him[al. om.] faste and longue
For-to defouli þis holie man &punctelev; with tormenz harde and strongue
¶ Þe Aumperores o cosin &punctelev; þat of gret power was
In-to toune cam þulke time &punctelev; ase it feol bi cas
Þe giwes weren so sore a-drad &punctelev; laste he hem bi-nome
Þoru&yogh; strencþe seint Barnabe &punctelev; and ladde him to rome
A-ni&yogh;ht huy nomen þis holie man &punctelev; ase he was to-raunsed so
And teiden ane rop a-boute is necke &punctelev; and knutten him faste þerto
And drowen him out of heore synagoge &punctelev; with seoruwe and pine i-nov&yogh;
And sethþe al-so bi þe sweore &punctelev; out atþe &yogh;ate men him drov&yogh;
And mauden a-boute him swiþe gret fuyr &punctelev; and barnden him al-to nou&yogh;te
his soule wende to þe Ioye of heouene &punctelev; þat he wel deore a-bou&yogh;te
¶ Þo nomen þe luþere men heore red &punctelev; &yogh;wanne huy mi&yogh;ten atþe laste
his bones þat weren bi-left vn-barnd &punctelev; a-midde þe .se. to caste
Ake cristine Men þat weren bi-side &punctelev; stelen to bi ni&yogh;te
And bureden as wel stilleliche &punctelev; with ase gret honour ase huy mi&yogh;te
Nov bidde we &yogh;eorne ihesu crist &punctelev; king of alle kinge
For loue of seint Barnabe &punctelev; þat he us to heouene bringue
SEint Iohan was þe beste bern &punctelev; þe holie baptist
Þat euere of womman was i-bore &punctelev; with-oute ihesu crist
Ake of al þat he on vrþe was &punctelev; we ne findez nou&yogh;t i-write
Þat he ani Miracle dude &punctelev; þat man mi&yogh;hte vnder-&yogh;ite
Mani men þinchez þerof wonder &punctelev; so guod man ase he was;
For manie miracles sum oþur dude &punctelev; þat fulliche so holi man nas
Ake al it was for þe luþere giwes &punctelev; þoru&yogh; ore louerdes wille so
For &yogh;if he hadde here on eorþe &punctelev; ani miracle i-do
Þo giwes wolden habbe i-went &punctelev; þat he ore louerd were
For he bi-gan ferst cristindom &punctelev; and þat folk þer-to lere
Þare-fore ore louerd dude miracles &punctelev; and ne liet him do non
For þe giwes scholden i-wite &punctelev; &yogh;wuch he were ech-on
¶ Seint Iohan for ore louerdes loue &punctelev; was sethþe i-brou&yogh;t of dawe
For-to holden up cristindom &punctelev; and þe ri&yogh;hte lawe
Heroudes, þat was þo king &punctelev; in a time to rome
Wende to þe Aumperour &punctelev; ase is wone was for-to done
So þat bi þe weie he wende &punctelev; bi sire phelipe, his broþur;
And maude gret feste, ase ri&yogh;t was &punctelev; heore eiþur with oþur
So þat heroudes spac &punctelev; mid is broþer wiue
Þe[r. þat] he hire wolde to wiue habbe &punctelev; þe &yogh;wuyle he were a-liue
And þat he wolde framward rome &punctelev; þare-forth a-&yogh;ein wende
And nimen hire and leden hire forth with him &punctelev; and holde hire is liues ende
At on a-cord huy weren sone &punctelev; to don þis sorie dede
Ase twei schrewene a-cordiet sone &punctelev; to ane luþere rede
¶ Þis kyng heroudes wende forth &punctelev; in is wei toward rome
And þou&yogh;te to take is broþer wijf &punctelev; &yogh;wane he a-&yogh;einward come
His owene wijf it vnder-&yogh;at &punctelev; ase sum freond hire word sende
to hire fader, þat [was] king &punctelev; of Damasche, sone heo i-wende
to beon þare forto heo wuste &punctelev; hou þis dede wolde an-ende
Þe king heroudes bi is broþer &punctelev; A-&yogh;einward gan eft i-wende
And, also it was er bi-speke &punctelev; þis wijf with him he nam
And heold hire with strencþe ase is owene &punctelev; in spous-bruche and horedam
And tiemde bi hire deolfolliche &punctelev; in sunne and with gret wou&yogh;
his broþer and is wiues fader &punctelev; weren with him wroþe i-nou&yogh;
And duden him harm bi al heore mi&yogh;hte &punctelev; and boþe weren is fon;
Ake he heold him faste in his folie &punctelev; and bi-lefde euere in on
¶ So þat seint Iohan þe Baptist &punctelev; to him a day com
And calangede him of is sunne[MS. sunnne] &punctelev; to ligge so in horedom
And seide, it was a-&yogh;ein heore lawe &punctelev; and a-&yogh;ein cristindom
Heroudes þare-fore in wrathþe &punctelev; seint Iohan wel faste nam
And, for-to paye þe luþere hore &punctelev; in strong prisun him caste
Þare-inne he lay al a &yogh;er &punctelev; i-warded strangue and faste;
And sethþe he liet smite of is heued &punctelev; as &yogh;e i-hereth ofte telle
Also man redez in is daye in heruest &punctelev; bi-foren eov in þe godspelle
¶ In þe Castel of Arabie &punctelev; is heued was of i-smite;
Þe luþere quene it bi-nam hire dou&yogh;ter &punctelev; and liet it faste wite
his desciples wenden stilleliche &punctelev; þoru&yogh; ore louerdes grace
And bureden þis holie bodi &punctelev; in a wel fair place
Bi-twe[ne] Abel and Elysee &punctelev; þat prophetes &yogh;wilene were
Stille was is holie bodi &punctelev; wel longue i-bured þere
¶ Þis false quene þat heued wuste &punctelev; þat men ne founden it nou&yogh;t
laste it were in ani time &punctelev; to þis bodie i-brou&yogh;t
And a rise fram deþe to liue &punctelev; and bi-come at þe laste
A prophete ase he was er— &punctelev; þere-fore heo wuste it faste
A day ase heo bi-heold þat heued &punctelev; inwardliche in þe face
heo feol a-doun ded a-non &punctelev; as it was ore louerdes grace
Þulke wreche to hire cam &punctelev; þat deth hire a-doun caste
Me þinchez heo ne ou&yogh;te nou&yogh;t bi-li&yogh;he &punctelev; hire schreuhede atþe laste;
Ne þat luþere best, hire dou&yogh;ter, noþer. &punctelev; for ase heo &yogh;eode a dai
And pleide upon .yse. in hire game &punctelev; ase mani a man it[r. i-] sai
Þat .ys. to-brak vnder hire &punctelev; and heo a-dronk a-non
And in þe deueles name (!) &punctelev; boþe flechs and bon
Þis hadde moder and eke Dou&yogh;ter &punctelev; to heore Mede atþen ende
And also schal ech luþur man &punctelev; &yogh;wanne vre louerd it wole him siende
¶ Þat heued was sethþe wel priueliche &punctelev; to Ierusalem i-brou&yogh;t
And i-bured stilleliche &punctelev; þat Men ne founden it nou&yogh;t
Of þis holi bodi, þare it lay &punctelev; manie Miracles come
Grete and faire, ny&yogh;ht and day &punctelev; ase þat folk i-sai&yogh; i-lome
A luþer Aumperour þere was þo &punctelev; þe luþere Iulian
Þa[t] reneyede ore louerdes lawe &punctelev; and was swyþe vuel Man
Þo Men tolden him of þis Miracles &punctelev; In grete wrathþe and onde
he liet nimen þis holie bones &punctelev; and to-sprede into al þe londe
And casten heom a-boute ech fram oþur &punctelev; þat no man þare-nei&yogh; ne come
Ne ne founden[r. founde] heom to fette is bote &punctelev; ase men duden er i-lome
Ake &yogh;ut for al is felonie &punctelev; ne bi-lefde ore louerd nou&yogh;t
Þat manie sike men þat comen þare-nei&yogh; &punctelev; to hele weren i-brou&yogh;t
¶ Þo was þis luþere Iulian &punctelev; wroþere þane he was er
Ase is bones weren er to-[s]prad &punctelev; his men he sende þer
And liet heom fette a&yogh;ein wel clene &punctelev; and with-oute þe toun a-non
he liet heom sette on strongue fuyre &punctelev; and fur-berne echon
And þut doust þar-of wel wide &punctelev; he liet blowe mid þe winde
For men ne scholden of him on vrþe &punctelev; neuereft more i-finde
Cominde toward baptisingue— &punctelev; ase attwelfte day
Toward þe watere of Iordan &punctelev; and loude gradde and cride and sede
"lo here godes lomb, þat bi-nimeth &punctelev; þe worldes mis-dede:"
For-soþe no fuyr ne mi&yogh;te come &punctelev; on þat fingur one;
Ake elles was al to douste i-barnd &punctelev; bodi and bones ech-one
No fuyr ne mi&yogh;hte þat finguer brenne &punctelev; for none cunnes þingue
Ake he bi-lefde hol, and &yogh;uyt is &punctelev; and þere nis non more bi-leued
On vrþe of him bote þilke fingur &punctelev; and his holie heued;
For al is bodi was for-barnd &punctelev; bote vnneþe þulke two
his day, ase falleth in heruest &punctelev; þis dede was i-do
¶ Þat is bodi was þus i-barnd. &punctelev; and also þulke day
Þer-aftur longue men founden is heued &punctelev; vnder vrþe ase it lay
Of þulke two þingues men holdeth is feste &punctelev; þanne, þat &yogh;e it wite;
For men ne mowen nou&yogh;t on ore leuedi day &punctelev; þo is heued was of i-smite
A manere martyrdom it was &punctelev; is bones so to-drawe
Þare-fore men mouwe þanne holde &punctelev; is feste bi ri&yogh;te lawe
¶ His holie heued, þat þus was &punctelev; at Ierusalem i-hud
Þoru&yogh; fair miracle of seint Iohan &punctelev; formest was i-kud
For to tweie Monekus at Ierusalem &punctelev; him-sulf he cam bi ni&yogh;hte
And schewede heom &yogh;ware is heued lay &punctelev; ase it were in a si&yogh;hte
huy wenden forth and sou&yogh;ten it[orig. is] sone &punctelev; and in þulke here i-wounde
Þat he werede in wildernesse &punctelev; atþe laste huy it founden;
And þane fyngur huy founden al-so &punctelev; þat was of him bi-leued
With gret honour huy beren forth &punctelev; þat fingur and þis h[e]ued
¶ For fair relike huy weren i-wust. &punctelev; and &yogh;ut atþe laste
Eft-sone huy weren &yogh;uyt i-hud &punctelev; and in a put i-caste
And leyen þare longue i-hudde &punctelev; ase fewe þar-of þou&yogh;te
Ake weren on vrþe al for-&yogh;ite &punctelev; ase no-man of heom ne rou&yogh;te
Bote seint Iohan it nolde nou&yogh;t &punctelev; þat huy lei&yogh;en to longue þere
To þe Abbod Marcel[MS. Maroel] he cam a ny&yogh;ht &punctelev; in metyngue ase it were
And bad him nime is heued up &punctelev; and seide &yogh;ware it lay
Þis guode man a-ros up sone &punctelev; and ne a-bod nou&yogh;t forto day
Ake he openede is celle dore &punctelev; and bi-heold a-boute
Ane steorre he fond bi-fore þe dore &punctelev; houinde þare-with-oute
Þe clereste steorre þat mi&yogh;hte beo— &punctelev; him wondrede þar-of i-nov&yogh;
he þonkede god with guode wille &punctelev; and toward þe steorre he drov&yogh;
And putte forth is hond and wolde hire take. &punctelev; ake he ne mi&yogh;hte hire nou&yogh;t a-reche
Ake þe steorre gan softe to glide forth &punctelev; also it were þene wey to teche
¶ þis Abbod hire siwede euere forth &punctelev; and þe steorre bi-fore wel softe
Þe Abbot Anourede his ledare &punctelev; fale siþes and ofte
Forth wende þe steorre, forto huy comen &punctelev; ouer þat ilke place
Þare his holie heue[d] lay &punctelev; þoru&yogh; ore louerdes grace;
Þo heo cam ouer þulke place &punctelev; heo houede þare ane stounde
For-to Marcel þis holie Monek &punctelev; hadde þis heued i-founde
¶ To þe guode bischop Iulian &punctelev; Marcel tolde þis cas
Þoru&yogh; heom boþe þat holie heued &punctelev; I-nomen up of þe vrþe was
his heued &yogh;ut, and is finguer al-so &punctelev; boþe huy beoth hole and sounde
A-seint Iohanes day in heruest[29 Aug.] &punctelev; þus huy weren i-founde
Þare-fore &yogh;uit þoru&yogh; heste of Rome &punctelev; so wijd so is cristindom
Men holdez þane dai in ho[nu]raunce[MS. hor|aunce] &punctelev; of is holi martyrdom
¶ For in ore leuedie daye in leynte &punctelev; as he was to deþe i-brou&yogh;t
For þe oþur festene þat þare beoth &punctelev; of him men ne redez nou&yogh;t
Nouþe seint Iohan þat in þe flym Iordan &punctelev; baptisede godes sone
Lieue us þoru&yogh; ore cristindom &punctelev; to þe Ioye of heouene come
SEint Iemes þe holi Apostle &punctelev; guod is to habbe in mone
Seint Iohanes broþur þe Ewangelist &punctelev; and ore louerdes aunte sone;
his Moder was ore leuedi soster &punctelev; Marie cleophe
Of guode kunne he was i-come &punctelev; non betere ne mi&yogh;hte be;
he au&yogh;hte wel him-self beo guod &punctelev; ase &yogh;e mowe alle i-se
In þe londe of Samarie he prechede &punctelev; and al-so in Ivde;
Þoru&yogh; is prechingue mani on &punctelev; he turnde to cristindom
To hermogenes þe luþere prince &punctelev; þe tiþingue sone com
¶ Þilke prince was wichche strong &punctelev; and enchauntour also
Þoru&yogh; þe deuel he wolde al day &punctelev; gret Miracle do
Ane desciple he hadde of is Art &punctelev; philet was is name
him he sende to seint Ieme &punctelev; to fondi to don him schame
&YOGH;if þat he mi&yogh;hte with is Art &punctelev; seint Ieme ouer-come
To-gadere huy comen forto playdi &punctelev; ase þe day was i-nome
Godes desciple and þe feondes &punctelev; bi-gonne to playdi faste;
Ac seint Ieme, þat was godes desciple &punctelev; a-boue was atþe laste
Blinde men he &yogh;af heore sij&yogh;ht &punctelev; and maude hole in þe place
Meseles and þe crokede al-so &punctelev; al þoru&yogh; ore louerdes grace
¶ Þo philet i-sai&yogh; him þus ouer-come &punctelev; to is maister he wende sone
Hermogenes, and tolde him fore &punctelev; ase is ri&yogh;hte was to done
"Sire," he seide, "ne hope þov nou&yogh;t &punctelev; to come seint Ieme with|Inne;
For nau&yogh;t it is, for þov ne schalt nou&yogh;t &punctelev; ouer-come him with al þi ginne
Þare-fore do ase ichulle þe rede &punctelev; and go we to him, we twei&yogh;e
And crie him merci and bicome we &punctelev; his desciples beye
For siker þou beo, ichulle it do &punctelev; þei þou nelle nou&yogh;t also."
So wroth was þe prince þat he nuste &punctelev; &yogh;wat for wrathþe do;
Þoru&yogh; strencþe of þe deueles Art &punctelev; he made philet a-non
Þat he ne mi&yogh;hte non more þane a stok &punctelev; a fot of þat stude gon
¶ "Nov," he seide, "we schullen i-seo &punctelev; &yogh;wat Iemes þe mai don here
&YOGH;weþer he þe mai a-&yogh;ein me vndo &punctelev; and a-&yogh;ein mine godes pouwere."
he liet him ligge þare ase astok &punctelev; and forth a-wei fram him wende
Philet nam ane man a-non &punctelev; and seint Ieme word sende
hou faste þoru þe deueles mi&yogh;hte &punctelev; he lai þer i-bounde
And bad him helpe his desciple &punctelev; and bringue þene deuel to grounde
¶ Seint Ieme him sende a luyte cloth &punctelev; þat he with him ber
Þat he touchede him þare-with &punctelev; and seide þeos two vers of þe sauter
"Ore louerd vn-bind þat beoth i-bounde &punctelev; and &yogh;if þe blinde is si&yogh;hte
Ore louerd ri&yogh;tht heom þat buth vn-ri&yogh;ht &punctelev; for þou louest[al. oure louerd loueþ] alle ri&yogh;hte."
¶ Þo philet hadde þis i-do &punctelev; ase seint Ieme word him sende
On-bounde he was of þe deueles bendes &punctelev; and &yogh;wodere he wolde he wende
he þrettnede faste hermogenes. &punctelev; to seint Ieme sone he cam
And godes desciple was and is &punctelev; and aveng cristindom
Þo hermogenes i-herde þis &punctelev; þat he was so vn-bounde
And þat seint Ieme hadde i-brou&yogh;t &punctelev; al is dede to grounde
¶ Manie deuelene he conIurede &punctelev; þat huy to him wende
"Wel &yogh;e wutez," he seide, "&yogh;wi it is &punctelev; þat ich after eov sende
Ore alre fo, Iemes, hath &punctelev; mine desciple me bi-nome
Bote &yogh;e beon strengore þane ich am &punctelev; i-wis we beoth ouer-come
Ich hote eov þat &yogh;e wenden a-non &punctelev; and doth a god prei&yogh;e
Nimeth and bringuet heom to me &punctelev; faste i-bounde bei&yogh;e
Certes, bote &yogh;e it mouwen do &punctelev; ase &yogh;e wel i-seoth
Ouwer power nis nou&yogh;t wurth an hawe &punctelev; for ouer-come we beoth."
¶ "We schulle sone," þe deuelene seiden &punctelev; "with heom on vrþe[Vern. a noþur] plei&yogh;e
Faste i-bounde al to þine wille &punctelev; we schulle heom bringue bey&yogh;e
huy comen fleo oppe in þe loft &punctelev; ouer þe apostle seint Ieme
And a-non so huy weren ouer him i-come &punctelev; huy guonne to grenne and reme,[al. feme]
Belewi and wel foule crie &punctelev; "Iemes, Iemes, þin ore
We brennez here are it ore tyme be &punctelev; and beth i-tormented ful sore."
"Ho tormentede[al. tormenteþ] eov," quath seint Ieme &punctelev; "and &yogh;wat wolde &yogh;e nouþe here?"
"Bote we buth i-come," þe feondes seiden &punctelev; "to nime þe and þi fere;
Hermogenes us made hidere wiende &punctelev; þoru&yogh; is conIuringue
Þat we eov scholden faste i-bounde &punctelev; bei&yogh;e to him bringue
Bote a-non so we comen here ouer þe &punctelev; Aungles to us come
With brenninde raketei&yogh;ene &punctelev; and faste vs bounde and nome;
here huy us beteth and tormentieth &punctelev; with brenninde fuyre
A wey, wei, Iemes, &yogh;wat schulle we do? &punctelev; we ne mowen nou&yogh;t þis duyre
A, Iemes, Iemes, leoue louerd &punctelev; of us wrechches haue reuþe
And neuereft we nelleth nei&yogh; þe come &punctelev; pli&yogh;hte we wolleth ore treouþe."
¶ "&YOGH;e wrechche foles," quath seint Ieme &punctelev; "I not &yogh;wat &yogh;e wolden here
Of þat &yogh;e þou&yogh;ten me a-nuye &punctelev; drawe &yogh;e schullen a-rere
Al on-bounde ich &yogh;yue eov leue &punctelev; a-&yogh;ein forto fleo
And bringuth him þat hidere eov sende &punctelev; faste i-bounde to me
Þat &yogh;e ne don him non oþur harm!— &punctelev; for icholde with him speke."
"Wel is us nouþe," þe schrewen seide &punctelev; "we worþet wel a-wreke."
¶ To hermogenes huy comen sone &punctelev; and to grounde him caste
huy drowen him and is hondene bounden &punctelev; bi-hinden him wel faste
Þus[al. þef] huy seiden, "þou sendest us &punctelev; þare we gret wo i-fielde
In gret torment and brenningue &punctelev; and nouþe we wollez þe &yogh;elde."
huy harleden forth þusne wrechche &punctelev; and to seint Ieme heo him brou&yogh;te
And seiden, "lo sire, &yogh;ware he is her &punctelev; þat to swuche torment us wrou&yogh;te
&YOGH;if us ferst leue þat we moten &punctelev; ore tormens a-wreke
And þe muchele vnri&yogh;ht þat he us hath ido &punctelev; are þou with him speke!"
¶ "Nay, certes," quath þis holie man &punctelev; "&yogh;e ne schullen nou&yogh;t so
For ore louerd us hiet þat we scholden &punctelev; guod for vuele do
&YOGH;wy ne come [&yogh;e] nou&yogh;t nei&yogh; philet &punctelev; þat stant here bi me?"
"Wel þou wost," þis oþure seiden &punctelev; "þat we ne moten for þe."
"No. goth þanne," quath seint Ieme &punctelev; "to eower kuynde stude
And ne cometh neuer-eft nei&yogh; no guod man &punctelev; þei a fol eov habbe i|bede."
¶ Euere stod hermogenes &punctelev; and criede milce and ore
he quakede for drede and for pine &punctelev; And wep swiþe sore
¶ "Philete, philete," quath seint Ieme &punctelev; "þes hath þe schame ido
Þov schalt don him guod a-&yogh;ein vuel &punctelev; for mi louerd het me so
Philet vn-bond þane wrechche &punctelev; and dude him vuel for guod
Þe wrechche ne dorste nou&yogh;woder gon for fere &punctelev; ake quakyinde þare he stod
"Go &yogh;ware þov wolt," quath seint Ieme &punctelev; "for mi louerd nele it nou&yogh;t
Þat euere ani man a-&yogh;ein is wille &punctelev; to him beo i-brou&yogh;t."
¶ "A, merci," quath hermogenes &punctelev; "þis deuelen me beteh[r. beten] so sore
Þat I-ne dar anne fot fram þe go &punctelev; laste huy me nimen more;
huy me wullez a-sle, &yogh;if huy me a-fongueth eft &punctelev; and þare-fore ich bidde þe
Þat þov me take sum þing þat ich mouwe &punctelev; for heom bere with me."
Seint Ieme him tok is staf on honde &punctelev; "go nov forth," he seide
"Þere nis no deuel þat dorre nouþe &punctelev; nei&yogh; þe come, for drede."
Hermogenes wende him forth. &punctelev; his bokes alle he nam
Þat he hadde of his enchauntemenz &punctelev; to þe Apostle a-&yogh;ein he cam
And bad þat he as for-brenne scholde. &punctelev; þe Apostle sone heom nam
And caste heom in þe deope .se &punctelev; faste i-bounde echon
¶ Hermogenes criede him merci &punctelev; and wilnede cristindom;
So þat he i-cristned was &punctelev; and swiþe holi man bi-cam.
Abiatar, þat þo was &punctelev; Iustise, luþur i-nov&yogh;
For þis dede he was wroth &punctelev; toward seint Ieme, with gret wou&yogh;
he nam him faste and swor is othþ &punctelev; þat he it scholde a-bugge deore;
to þe kyingue heroudes he liet him lede &punctelev; a rop a-boute is swere
Heroudes &yogh;af his dom a-non &punctelev; his þrote to smite a-two
And Iosie þe quellare he was bi-take &punctelev; þulke dede for-to do
Ane Rop he dude a-boute is necke &punctelev; and ladde him toward is dome
Ane Man he helde of þe palasie &punctelev; are heo þudere come
Þo Iosie þis isai&yogh; &punctelev; merci anon he criede;
Seint Ieme þe holie Apostle &punctelev; he bad wel sone a-bide
And cristni him in þe place &punctelev; a-non-ri&yogh;tes þere
A-seinte marie day in leinte &punctelev; bi-haueded boþe heo were
Ake holie curche halt of ore leuedi &punctelev; feste þat ilke day;
Bi-fore lamasse seueni&yogh;ht &punctelev; we holdeth is day þer-fore,[MS. bi-fore]
For þulke daye is bodi was &punctelev; in-to schrine i-bore
¶ A-non so seint Ieme þe holie man &punctelev; bi-haueded was þere
his desciples him wolden lede a-wei &punctelev; ac huy ne dorsten for fere
heore tyme huy a-wayteden wel &punctelev; &yogh;wanne none Men þare nei&yogh; nere
And þat bodi wel stilleliche &punctelev; out of þe countreye bere
In a schip huy leiden it in þe se &punctelev; and forth þare-withþ huy wende
And none &yogh;eme ne nomen &yogh;woderward fare &punctelev; bote ase god he[m] kende
Þat schip wende forth bi him-seolf &punctelev; and hit cam on a day
Into þe lond of Galeis &punctelev; þare ase þe quene lay
Þat luþur [was] and schrewe inov&yogh;. &punctelev; seint Iemes Men a-non
Op of þe schipe nomen þat holie bodi &punctelev; and leiden it opon a ston
Þe ston bi-gan to wexe a-brod &punctelev; and holu&yogh; bi-cam a-midde
Ase euene i-maud to þe holie bodi &punctelev; as ani man wolde bidde
¶ Ne scholde no man so euene a þrov&yogh; &punctelev; in lengþe and i[n] brede
To[al. make to] him ase þat ston bi-cam &punctelev; ase ech man þat it i-sai&yogh; seide
his desciples, ase it was ri&yogh;ht &punctelev; to þe Quene erest wende
"Dame," huy seiden, "we habbeth i-brou&yogh;t &punctelev; þat ore louerd þe hider sende
Seint Iemes bodi his Apostle &punctelev; of &yogh;wam þov nome ofte þi red
To laten him nime þe &yogh;wyle he was quik &punctelev; ase mani men it habbeth i-seid
Ore louerd him hath hidere i-sent &punctelev; ase he him-seolf bed.[orig. bad]
Loke &yogh;ware þov him legge wolt &punctelev; for i-come he is to þe ded."
¶ "Ey, traytours," quath þe luþere Quen &punctelev; "&yogh;weþer &yogh;e beon of his
&YOGH;wane i-ne mi&yogh;hte of him beo a-wreke &punctelev; of eov ichulle, i-wis."
Þis guode Men he nam ech-one &punctelev; and to þe king of spaygne heom sende
Þat he heom brou&yogh;te to strong dethþe &punctelev; oþur don heom heore lawe wende
Echone þe king nam a-non &punctelev; and in strongue prisone heom brou&yogh;te
Ac ore louerd ne for-&yogh;at heom nou&yogh;t &punctelev; ake wel sone on heom þou&yogh;te
For an Aungel fram heouene cam &punctelev; and þat prisoun brak wel sone
Þo þe kyng was þar-of i-war &punctelev; he nuste &yogh;wat was to done
¶ Kny&yogh;htes he liet siende i-nowe &punctelev; aftur heom wel wide;
Þat febleliche a-gonne in heore neodes &punctelev; for schame heom gan bi-tide
For ase huy wolden ouer ane hei&yogh;e brugge &punctelev; after þis guode men gon
Vnder heom þe brugge brak &punctelev; and huy a-drounken ech-on
¶ Þo þe tyþingue to þe kingue cam &punctelev; sori he was i-nov&yogh;;
Of is luþere [þou&yogh;t][om.] þat he þou&yogh;te &punctelev; for drede he him with-drov&yogh;
Mildeliche he to heom he sende &punctelev; þat huy a-&yogh;ein comen him to
And þat he heom wolde a-mendi faire &punctelev; of al þat he hadde heom mis-do
A&yogh;ein huy wenden to þe kyng &punctelev; and he faire a-&yogh;ein heom cam
&YOGH;ware-þoru&yogh; he and al is Men &punctelev; a-fenguen cristinedom
¶ Þe king sende þe Quene word &punctelev; þat heo scholde heore wille al do
Ful sori was þe Quene þo &punctelev; and sore a-nuyd al-so;
Ake heo ne dorste nou&yogh;t beo a&yogh;ein is heste &punctelev; nere hire no so [wo]
Wilde bollokes heo wuste fale &punctelev; ope ane hei&yogh;e hulle go
"Gothþ," heo seide, "ope þulke hulle &punctelev; finde &yogh;e mowen þere
Oxene and Bolen strongue inov&yogh; &punctelev; forte leden with ouwer bere;
Tei&yogh;eth heom to þulke wayne &punctelev; and þat bodi leggez þar-inne
And ledeth it &yogh;ware eouwere wille beo— &punctelev; godes leue &yogh;e habbe and minne."
¶ For þe Bollokes wilde were &punctelev; þe luþere Quene so seide
For huy ne scholden heom temie nou&yogh;t &punctelev; eni-þing for-to lede
his desciples wenden forth &punctelev; to þulke hulle hei&yogh;e
A fuyr Drake þar-opon &punctelev; a-&yogh;ein heom cominde huy sei&yogh;e
Swiþe ferliche he blaste fuyr &punctelev; and a-sayllede heom faste
Mani a man he hadde a-slawe &punctelev; and al þe contreie of him a-gaste
¶ Þis desciples mauden þe signe sone &punctelev; of þe Creoyz heom bi-fore
Anon hadde þis luþere worm &punctelev; is pouwer al ilore
Þat hit ne mi&yogh;hte ane fot forþere passe. &punctelev; þis desciples forth wende
And to-pouneden it al to deþe &punctelev; and ech lime fram oþur rende
Þe Bollokes and þe &yogh;oungue steores &punctelev; þat weren er so wilde
Anon so huy touward heom[superscribed.] come &punctelev; huy woxen tame and milde
Þe beste huy chosen þat huy wolden &punctelev; and to þe wayne heom ladde;
And huy drowen þat bodi so mildeliche &punctelev; þat ech man þarof wonder hadde
¶ Þis desciples nomen seint Iemes bodi &punctelev; and opon þe wayne it leide
Þe bestes it drowen forth wel mildeliche &punctelev; with-oute eche fole breide
huy comen and driue þane wayn &punctelev; þare as þe Quene was
hire wondrede muche and dradde sore &punctelev; þo heo isei&yogh; þat cas
¶ Heo for-sok hire false bi-leue &punctelev; and tok hire to cristindom
For þe wonder þat heo isei&yogh; &punctelev; and guod womman bicom
Al hure paleys þat heo was inne &punctelev; and al heore oþure bone
For-to honouri þat holie bodi &punctelev; heo grauntede heom wel sone
A-midde þe paleys þis holi bodi &punctelev; huy bureden with grete pruyte
Þare he hath euereft to þis dai i-beo &punctelev; and so he is &yogh;uyte
¶ Heo liet arere ane noble churche &punctelev; and gret tresor he &yogh;af þar-to
And gret lond, þat &yogh;uyt þare-to lijth &punctelev; and grete rentes al-so
&YOGH;ware-þoru&yogh; of religioun &punctelev; a gret hous nouþe þare is
Of Chanones, þat Men &yogh;eot i-seoth and sechethþ &punctelev; at seint Iemes of Galys
A gret pilegrimage it is i-holde &punctelev; ouer-al, ase &yogh;e i-seothþ
To sechen þat ilke holie stude &punctelev; þare seint Iemes bones beothþ
Mani miracle is pilegrimes seggeth &punctelev; þat þare hath ofte i-come
Þei we ne mouwen nou&yogh;t alle telle &punctelev; þenche we moten on some.
¶ Þritti Men at one tyme &punctelev; pilegrimes bi-come
To seint Iemes þe holie stude &punctelev; alle þene wei huy nome
Ase huy wenden bi þe wei&yogh;e &punctelev; so gret loue huy hadden and trewe
And so guod heorte ech to oþur hadde &punctelev; þat a foreward huy mauden newe
Þat non ne scholde failli oþur &punctelev; in perile ne in neode
Ake wed-breþerne huy bi-comen echon &punctelev; ase huy þat wei eode
heore treuþes huy pli&yogh;hten alle bote on &punctelev; ake he nolde his nou&yogh;t pli&yogh;te
Ake þat foreward he bi-het to holde &punctelev; treuweliche ope al is mi&yogh;hte
¶ So þat it bi-feol bi þe weie &punctelev; þat on i-vuelede a day
And vnder þe hulle of seint Mi&yogh;hel &punctelev; longue sijk he lay
his felawes þat hadde him treouþe i-pli&yogh;ht &punctelev; fiftene dawes þere
Abiden him; so þat heom þou&yogh;te longue &punctelev; for sore a-nuyde huy were
And seiden, "we ne mouwen no leng a-bide &punctelev; late we him ligge[ligge on the margin.] stille;
Do we moten ore pilegrimage &punctelev; god do bi him is wille."
huy nomen heore leue and lieten him ligge &punctelev; and wenden forth ech-on
Bote þilke þat nolde is treuþe pli&yogh;hte— &punctelev; he nolde nou&yogh;t fram him gon
¶ "Certes," he seide, "god do is wille &punctelev; and lieue eov wel to wende
I nelle anne fot fram him gon &punctelev; are ich wute of him sum ende."
Mid him he bi-lefde al one &punctelev; for-to þat he ded were
Betere is trewe dede þane fals word &punctelev; as it was isene þere
Þis trewe Man þat was with þe bodi &punctelev; ful sore a-drad he was
For he was so feor fram toune &punctelev; and no man nei&yogh;h him nas;
For he was with þe dede al one &punctelev; and it was nei&yogh;h ni&yogh;hte
he nuste &yogh;wat with þat bodi to do &punctelev; bote seint Ieme him helpe mi&yogh;hte
his help he bad with guode heorte. &punctelev; and in þe eueningue ri&yogh;ht
Seint Ieme cam to him ride &punctelev; in wel fair a-tyr of kni&yogh;ht
¶ "Cum here," he seide, "forth with me &punctelev; ne haue þou of no-þing drede
Bi-fore me cast þat bodi her &punctelev; and ich it wolle hennes lede
And lupe þou up bi-hynde me." &punctelev; and þo þis was al ido
Þis holie Man ladde þene dede forth &punctelev; and þene quike al-so
Fyftene Iorneies grete are day— &punctelev; in þulke luytele &yogh;wile,
To þe mount of Ioie &punctelev; þat is bi-sides seint Iemes a mile
Þo huy comen to þulke Mount &punctelev; seint Ieme gan a-bide
"Go," he seide to þe quike manne &punctelev; "to mine churche here-bi-side
And sei&yogh;e mine Canones þat þarinne beoth &punctelev; þat ich heom word bi þe sende
Mine pilegrim þat me was leof &punctelev; þat in treowenesse mine wei wende
Þat huy him burien a-mong heom þere &punctelev; with fair seruise and li&yogh;hte
For ded he schal þudere come &punctelev; &yogh;wane he a-liue ne mi&yogh;hte
And seie heom þat þine felawes were &punctelev; þat heore wei is al i-lore
For heore treouþe þat huy breke &punctelev; heore felawe, þat is nov bi-fore
And þine &yogh;wyle ichulle þe &yogh;elde &punctelev; þat þou hast þus treowe i-beo."
Mid þusse worde he wende forth &punctelev; þat he ne mi&yogh;hte him none-more i-se
¶ A-boute þat bodi for þis Miracle &punctelev; folk cam þicke reke
Here man mai sum-del i-seo &punctelev; &yogh;wuch [it is] treouþe to breke
And &yogh;wuch it is þane holie wey &punctelev; to seint Iemes forto go
Þis Miracle is so Murie &punctelev; ich mot &yogh;eot telle of mo.
¶ Hit was a guod man and is sone &punctelev; þat toward seint Iemes wende;
To þe cite of Tolouse &punctelev; a-&yogh;ein eue huy hem kende
Al ni&yogh;ht huy bi-lefden þere &punctelev; at ane luþere mannes Inne
he þou&yogh;te with &yogh;wuche tricherie &punctelev; he mi&yogh;hte panewes winne
¶ Nou was þe lawe in þulke stude &punctelev; as þe schrewe wel onder-stod
Þat ho-so an-hengue anine[r. anne] man &punctelev; he scholde habbe al is guod
Þe schrewe heom made fair semblaunt &punctelev; ase is manere was to done
Þat huy were for-dronke beie &punctelev; and a-slepe lei&yogh;en sone
A coppe of seluer stilleliche &punctelev; þis luþere Man gan bringue
And dude in heore schrippe softeliche &punctelev; a-mong heore oþur þingue
¶ Þis guode Man a-wok and is sone &punctelev; so sone so it dai was
And nomen heore leue and wenden forth &punctelev; and nusten nou&yogh;t of þat cas
Þo huy come with-oute toune a luyte &punctelev; þis luþere man aftur cam
hotinde out, with grete siwte &punctelev; and þis trewe men beie he nam
And seide huy hadden is coppe i-stole &punctelev; and in heore scrippe i-bounde
Þat folk þis i-liefde a-non &punctelev; þo huy þe coppe founde
¶ Þis pilegrimes, þei huy treowe weren &punctelev; to dome weren i-brou&yogh;t
Eche manere þeofþe huy fur-soken &punctelev; ake þat folk ne liefde heom nou&yogh;t
For huy weren i-nome hond habbinde &punctelev; þe court lokede a-non
Þat huy heore dom with heom beren &punctelev; and hanguy scholde þat on
¶ "Alas, alas," þe fader seide &punctelev; "&yogh;weþur i schulle novþe hongue
And are ich habbe seint Ieme i-sou&yogh;t &punctelev; þis file dethþ a-fongue?"
"Nai certes," quath is sone &punctelev; "þat nolde ich graunti þe
For to beo louerd of al þe world &punctelev; þat þov deidest bi-fore me
hanguy ichulle for us boþe &punctelev; þene deth i-nelle nou&yogh;t for-sake
And al-so wis ase we gultlese beoth &punctelev; mine soule ich god bi-take."
"A, mi leoue sone," quath þe fader &punctelev; "so ne schal it nou&yogh;t beo;
Scholdest þou dei&yogh;e and ich libbe &punctelev; i-nelle neuere þane day i-seo
Swuch a child touward as þou art &punctelev; i-loked it were wroþe
Þat þov scholdest hanguy and ich libbe! &punctelev; ichulle hangy for us boþe."
"A, fader, fader," quath þe sone &punctelev; "be stille, ich bidde þe
For I nelle neuere þane day a-bide &punctelev; þat þou schulle hongue bi-fore me;
¶ Ake go þane wey for us boþe &punctelev; and ichulle hangy for us beye
And bide seint Ieme þat he me graunti &punctelev; sum part of þine weye."
Bi-twene þe fader and þe sone &punctelev; þe striuingue laste longue
Þat ech man hadde deol þerof— &punctelev; &yogh;weþur scholde þene dethþ a-fongue
So þat it ful atþenende &punctelev; þei it were with wrongue
Þat þe sone for heom bei&yogh;e &punctelev; gulteles was an-hongue
¶ Alas, alas, þe deolfole cas &punctelev; to heore so muche falshede
Wel &yogh;eorne boþe fader and sone &punctelev; seint Ieme help huy bede
Welle louerd, þe deol of þe fader— &punctelev; grettore neuere non nas
Þo he isai&yogh; is sone an-hongue &punctelev; and for he gulteles was
he bi-tey&yogh;te is soule Iesu crist &punctelev; þo þare nas non oþur won
And is wei with sorewe i-nov &punctelev; to seint Iemes he gan gon
Also wel for is sone ase for him &punctelev; seint Ieme he bad faste;
And wende, þo he hadde al ido &punctelev; hamward at þe laste
Are he come þare is sone was &punctelev; him þou&yogh;te swyþe longue
&YOGH;if he mi&yogh;hte finde oþur i-seo &punctelev; ani lime of him hongue
For þe lawe was þere þat euerech man &punctelev; þat an-hangued were
hanguy scholde þe &yogh;wyle i-laste[al. he laste] &punctelev; and for-to ech lime fram oþur to-tere
¶ Þis &yogh;oungue Man sixe and þritti dawes &punctelev; heng up-on þe galu-treo
Are is fader a-&yogh;ein to him come &punctelev; þat i-roted he au&yogh;te to beo
he cam and fond him &yogh;uyt &punctelev; and ner him he gan teo
he weop and criede and wrong is hondene &punctelev; þat deol it was to seo
¶ "Leoue fader," þe sone seide &punctelev; "ne weop þou nou&yogh;t to bliue
For ich nam to bi-weope nou&yogh;t &punctelev; &yogh;eot ich am a-liue
Me nas neuere on eorþe so wel &punctelev; ase me hath sethþe i-beo;
Ich am ase þei ich were in heouene &punctelev; þei ich hanguy here on þis treo
For seint Ieme me halt up &punctelev; and Ioye i-nov&yogh; me dieth make
Me of-þuncheth þat þou so sone come &punctelev; laste þov me a-doun take."
Louerd, þe Ioye þat þe fader &punctelev; hadde þulke stounde
Þo he aftur al is sor &punctelev; his sone a-liue founde
¶ To toune he orn with Ioye i-nou&yogh; &punctelev; and cleopede folk wel faste
Muche folk him siwede and al þe soþe &punctelev; i-sei&yogh;en atþe laste
Withþ gret Ioye huy nomen him a-doun &punctelev; and to þe toune him brou&yogh;ten
Þene traitur þat him maude an-hongue &punctelev; wel sone out huy sou&yogh;ten
And an-henguen him wel hei&yogh;e a-non &punctelev; and nou&yogh;t bote he wuyrþe were
Þus seint Ieme þe holie man &punctelev; is pilegrim halp þere.
¶ In þe Cite of leouns &punctelev; a &yogh;oung man þare was al-so
Þat ofte wende to seint Iemes &punctelev; and gret loue hadde þar-to
At one tyme ase he þudere wolde &punctelev; he dude er ane folie
Þat manie Men to helle bringueth &punctelev; þe sunne of lecherie;
Toward seint Iemes he wende forthþ &punctelev; are he i-schriue were
Þe deuel was wel &yogh;eorne a-boute &punctelev; &yogh;if he mi&yogh;hte him mis-lere
¶ A-&yogh;ein him he cam in þe wei &punctelev; swiþe milde and softe
Ri&yogh;ht ase it seint Ieme were &punctelev; ase þe schrewe gyleth men wel ofte
"&YOGH;wost þou euere," he seide, "ho ich am?" &punctelev; þe &yogh;oungue man seide nay
"Icham þilke," he seide, "þat þov hast &punctelev; I-serued wel mani a day
Seint Ieme to-ward &yogh;wam þou art. &punctelev; I ne may make no mone
Of þe þat þov wel ne dest &punctelev; of eche þingue bote of one
Þat þou dust[MS. dẹust; dust=dudest] lecherie &punctelev; are þou wendest to me;
Among alle men, &yogh;if þat nere &punctelev; mest ich preisie þe."
¶ "Seint Ieme, merci," quath þis man &punctelev; "ich crie þe milce and ore
For&yogh;if me þulke luþere sunne &punctelev; i-nelle don as neuereft more."
"Ov, beau frere," quath þe schrewe &punctelev; "strong is þe mis-dede
Þov ne mi&yogh;ht me neuere paye wel &punctelev; bote þov do ase ich rede
Þe menbre þov most keruen of &punctelev; &yogh;ware-withþ þou i-sunegut hast;
Þe sunne ichulle for-&yogh;iue þe þanne &punctelev; &yogh;wanne he is fram þe i-cast;
Ak next me þou scholdest in Ioye beo &punctelev; in þe blisse of heouene a-boue
&YOGH;if þou woldest beon a martyr &punctelev; and þi-seolf martri for mi loue."
¶ "A, louerd seint Ieme," quath þis man &punctelev; "þov haue merci of me
Ichulle, mine sunnes to bete, mi-sulf martri &punctelev; and forto pay&yogh;e þe."
Þis wrechche Man carf of is membres &punctelev; and a-wei fram him caste
And sethþe þoru&yogh; þe false þeues rede &punctelev; him-self he a-slov&yogh; atþe laste
Ful redi was þe schrewe þer &punctelev; þe soule he nam a-non
And wel glad þare-with in his manere &punctelev; to-ward helle he gan gon
Ne fur-&yogh;at nou&yogh;t seint Ieme is pilegrim &punctelev; for þat cas þat him gan bi|tide
A-&yogh;ein þe deuel he cam a-doun &punctelev; and bad þane schrewe a-bide
And seide, "þou berst more þane þin owe. &punctelev; þat i schal kuyþe þe
&YOGH;wi hast þou mine pilegrim bi-traid? &punctelev; gret schame þou dest me."
"&YOGH;e, al for nau&yogh;t," quath þe schrewe &punctelev; "þou art hidere i-come
In his sunne him-sulf he a-slou&yogh; &punctelev; and þare-with ich him habbe i|nome
Ne may no man in dedlich sunne &punctelev; in-to heuene wende
Ase wel þou mi&yogh;ht gon hom a-&yogh;ein &punctelev; he is min with-outen enden."
¶ "Bel amy," quath seint Ieme &punctelev; "þou bi-traidest him with fals|hede
And with tricherie þou to him come. &punctelev; lat him gon, ich rede!"
"Ich habbe leue," quath þe schrewe &punctelev; "to bi-gyli and bi-traye al-so
Mid eche quointise þat ich mai. &punctelev; &yogh;wi wolde he aftur me do?"
Þis strif i-laste bi-twene hem longue. &punctelev; ake þo seint Ieme ne mi&yogh;hte
habbe þe soule ne with-inne him come &punctelev; with no resun ne ri&yogh;hte
"Þou schalt," he seide, "come with me &punctelev; to an herre Iustise
Þat þe schal cuyþe þi tricherie &punctelev; of &yogh;wam þe schal a-grise."
Bi-fore ore leuedi swete and milde &punctelev; þane schrewe he gan lede;
he &yogh;al and quakede deolfulliche &punctelev; þo he i-sei&yogh; hire, for drede
¶ "Þov luþere þing," ore leuedi seide &punctelev; "&yogh;wi fondeste in alle wise
To bi-nime us and bi-trai&yogh;e men &punctelev; þat beth in ovre seruise
Þou ne schalt neuere þe soule brouke &punctelev; for þine tricherie."
"leoue leuedi," quath þe schrewe &punctelev; "merci ich þe crie
Vnder-stond þat ich habbe leue &punctelev; to bi-gylie men inou&yogh;
And þat ich fond him in dedlich sunne &punctelev; and þare-inne him-sulf he slov;
And no man neuere in swuch cas &punctelev; to heuene come ne mi&yogh;hte
Ase he is min mid alle lawe &punctelev; hold me, ich bidde, to ri&yogh;hte!"
¶ "Þov luþere best," ore leuedi seide &punctelev; "to muche ower pouwer is
Alas þat men nellez beon i-war &punctelev; are huy don a-mis
Ase þou mid þine tricherie &punctelev; his lijf him bi-nome
Al-so ichulle him &yogh;iuen a-&yogh;ein &punctelev; is lijf with ri&yogh;hte dome
So þat þe ne tit of him no part &punctelev; for guod man he wo[l] &yogh;eot be."
Ore leuedi made þe soule a-non &punctelev; to þe bodi a&yogh;en fleo;
Fram deþe to liue he a-ros &punctelev; þoru&yogh; ore leuedi ore
And guod lijf ladde euere aftur-ward &punctelev; and þe deuel doutede þe more
¶ His menbres, þat he carf of &punctelev; euer-eft he dude misse
Bote a luytel wise &yogh;ware-þoru&yogh; he mi&yogh;hte &punctelev; &yogh;wane he wolde, pisse
Manie Men for þulke miracle &punctelev; seint Ieme louieth þe more
Nou bidde we &yogh;eorne euerech-one &punctelev; seint Ieme milse and ore
Þat he for þat holie stude &punctelev; þat he hath in galiz
helpe us and alle is pilegrimes &punctelev; and bringue us to heouene blis
SEint Oswold þe holie king &punctelev; of þe on ende of enguelonde
King was, ase þulke tyme bi-feol &punctelev; in northþ-homber-londe
Cristine man he was guod i-nov&yogh; &punctelev; and with al is pouwer
he heold up þe lawe of cristindom &punctelev; and tei&yogh;te as feor and ner
For he was king are cristindom &punctelev; puyrliche stable were
Al is men þar-to he brou&yogh;te &punctelev; so wijsliche he gan heom lere
To þe princes he sende of scoth-lond &punctelev; and bad þat huy him sende
Ane wise clerk, is men to wissi &punctelev; heore lijf forto amende
huy senden him ane holie man &punctelev; þat icleoped was aydan
Þat wende and prechede al is lond &punctelev; and tornede mani a man
¶ Þoru&yogh; is prechingue and seint Oswold &punctelev; þat to alle guodnesse hem drov&yogh;
Cristindom into al þat lond &punctelev; stable was i-nou&yogh;
Seint Oswold maude þesne holie man &punctelev; Bischop in is londe
And made him al is conseiler &punctelev; and herede godes sonde;
he ne dude noþing with-outen him &punctelev; ake with him he heold him faste
And to-gadere al heore lijf huy weren &punctelev; and in heouene atþe laste
¶ A day ase he sat and eat is mete &punctelev; seint oswold þe holie man
And þis holie man bi him &punctelev; þe Bischop guode aydan
Þat o seriaunt[MS. seriannt] seide þat þare withoute &punctelev; manie pouere men were
And beden sum guod for godes loue &punctelev; and guod was þat men him[r. hem] bere
Þe king nam inov&yogh; of is mete &punctelev; þat bi-fore him stod
And sende þar-of wel largeliche &punctelev; heom þat beden him guod
Ane Dischs of seluer he nam also &punctelev; þat bi-fore him was i-do
And to-brak it al to smale peces &punctelev; and sende heom al-so
Þe Bischop sat and bi-heold &punctelev; ase þei he were in þou&yogh;te
Bi þe hond þe king he nam &punctelev; and a swete word out brou&yogh;te
"Ne for-rotie neuere þis hond &punctelev; ake i-blessed be heo," he sede
"And euere hol and sound bi-leue &punctelev; þat dude so guod a dede!"
¶ His bone was fole wel i-heord. &punctelev; for it bi-feol atþe laste
Þat heþene men come in-to is lond &punctelev; and weorreden on him wel faste
he stod a-&yogh;ein with al is mi&yogh;hte. &punctelev; so bi-feol þat huy come
And i-metten heom with heore host &punctelev; and þe batayle nome
At þe tounne of Maserfeld &punctelev; huy smiten to-gadere faste
And seint Oswold þe holie Man &punctelev; a-slawe was atþe laste
¶ And I-martred of þis luþere men &punctelev; for ore louerdes loue
Al huy to-heowen is bodi &punctelev; þo huy weren a-boue;
Ake huy ne mi&yogh;hten for no þing &punctelev; makie none wonde
In noþer of is holie hond &punctelev; ake smiten as of hole and sounde
And so huy beoth &yogh;eot, of ase fair heu&yogh; &punctelev; ase huy euerer were
And i-holde for fair relike &punctelev; ase men mowe i-seo þere
¶ He was of ei&yogh;te and þritti &yogh;er &punctelev; þo he i-martred was,[a. 642]
And Nye &yogh;er he hadde king ibeo— &punctelev; bote luytel &yogh;wile it nas
Nov seint Oswold þe swete Martyr &punctelev; ore erinde to gode beode
Þat he us for-&yogh;iue ore sunnes &punctelev; and us helpe at alle ore neode
And ore soule for is swete loue &punctelev; in-to blisse lede
SEint Edward þe &yogh;ungue &punctelev; was kyng of Enguelonde
Wel &yogh;oung he i-martred was &punctelev; þoru&yogh; tricherie and onde
Þo is Moder þe guode Quene &punctelev; ase god wolde, was ded
his fader nam an oþur wijf &punctelev; þat luþur was and qued;
Þat sent Edward louede luyte &punctelev; and euere radde luþur red
Bi hure he hadde ane oþur sone &punctelev; þat i-hote was Atheldred
¶ Þe Quene louede hire owene [sone][om.] &punctelev; ase ech man deth is blod;
Ake seint Edward heo louede luyte— &punctelev; for stepmoder is selde guod
heo wilnede more þane ani-þing &punctelev; þat seint Edward ded were
Þat hire owene sone aftur þe king &punctelev; þe heritage bere
Þo þe king wende out of þis world &punctelev; seint Edward, and[r. as?] is sone
Aftur him was king j-mad &punctelev; ase lawe was and wone
¶ Þe guodnesse of þis &yogh;oungue king &punctelev; ne may no man telle
he was meoke and milde inou&yogh; &punctelev; and fair of flechs and felle
De-bonere for-to speke with &punctelev; ant with pouere men mest
Chaste, and wis of conseil &punctelev; and pruyte he louede lest;
Wylde Men ne louede he nou&yogh;t &punctelev; þat rechelese weren of þou&yogh;te
And wise Men to him he drou&yogh; &punctelev; and aftur heom he wrou&yogh;te
Aftur þe Erchebischope of Caunterburij &punctelev; seint Dunston þat was þo
Ech dede þat he wolde do &punctelev; þe meste del scholde go
Glad was þe holie man of him &punctelev; and al þat lond also
Of swuch a king þat heore louerd was &punctelev; þat alle þing wolde wel do
Guod pais þare was in Enguelonde &punctelev; and loue and muruþe i-nov&yogh;
Richesse and al oþur guod &punctelev; elles it were &yogh;wov&yogh;
For &yogh;wanne þat heued hathþ godes grace &punctelev; and loueth alle guode
Wonder it were bote alle his &punctelev; þe betere heom onder-stode
¶ To þe guodnesse of þis holie Man &punctelev; þe deuel hadde envie
And is stepmoder þe luþere Quene &punctelev; þat ful was of tricherie;
For heo þou&yogh;te Ni&yogh;ht and day &punctelev; &yogh;if heo mi&yogh;hte in ani manere
Þat seint Edward were a-slawe &punctelev; and hire sone kyng were
For he was eldest aftur him &punctelev; and þe kingues sone al-so
Þis luþere wumman narewe hire bi-þou&yogh;te &punctelev; hou þis mi&yogh;hte beo do
To some þat weren hire conseilers &punctelev; hire luþere þou&yogh;t he[= heo] seide
þat huy holpen with some Gyle &punctelev; to don þat luþere dede;
Þis luþere[MS. þuþere] Men also forthþ with hire &punctelev; weren in grete þou&yogh;te
With &yogh;wuche gyle huy mi&yogh;hten do &punctelev; þat huy to ende [it] brou&yogh;te
¶ So þat heo hadde to hire conseil &punctelev; I-nowe atþenende
For fellere þing nis non ase wumman &punctelev; &yogh;ware heo wole to vuele wende
Nadde þis &yogh;ungue king i-beo &punctelev; in is kynedom vnneþe
Bote þreo &yogh;er and Ey&yogh;hte dawes &punctelev; þat he nas i-brou&yogh;t to deþe
For a day he wente on hontethþ &punctelev; with is kni&yogh;htes bi cas
In a fayr wode in deorsete &punctelev; þat bi-side waraygne was
Fair wode þare was þulke tyme &punctelev; ake nouþe heo is al a-doune
Bote þornes and þunne boskes &punctelev; þat stondeth bi-sides þe toune
¶ Ase þis &yogh;oungue king wende on hontethþ &punctelev; a gret wille him cam to
For-te seo is &yogh;oungue[MS. &yogh;onngue] broþur &punctelev; and in eche manere he wolde it do
For he was þere a luyte bi-side &punctelev; ase is stepmoder was
In a toun þat men clepeden Corf &punctelev; þat bote þreo Mile þanne it nas
A strong castel þare is nouþe &punctelev; ake þe &yogh;uyt nas non þere
Þis holie man þou&yogh;te longue &punctelev; are he at is broþur were;
Ane fewe men with him he nam &punctelev; and þuderward he gan ride
his Men pleiden and Arnden bi þe weie &punctelev; and spradden a-boute ful wide
So þat with heom[r. him] ne bi-lefde non &punctelev; al one he was sone;
Ake naþeles forth he wende is wei &punctelev; ase he þou&yogh;te to done
Þe court he bi-heold a-fer &punctelev; þare ase is broþer was
Þudere he wende wel mildeliche &punctelev; ake no man with him nas
he ne þou&yogh;te to no man bote guod &punctelev; ne no man he nadde mis-do
To-war[d] is deþe forthþ he wende &punctelev; and mildeliche al-so
Þo is stepmoder þe luþere Quiene &punctelev; al one i-sei&yogh; him come
heo þou&yogh;te to don hire wille of him &punctelev; ase heo hadde hire red i-nome
Þe luþere Men heo cleopede sone &punctelev; þat weren at hire rede
And bi-speken bi &yogh;wuche feolonie &punctelev; to don þis luþere dede
¶ þo þis holie Man was nei&yogh; i-come &punctelev; þe Quiene a-&yogh;ein him eode
With fair Meyne and gret honour &punctelev; and gret loue gan him beode
þe feste þat heo with him made &punctelev; no tongue telle ne may
And swor þat he scholde a-li&yogh;te &punctelev; and with hire bi-leue alday
"Nai certes, dame," seide þis king &punctelev; "so ne may it nou&yogh;t beo
Ake lat me speke with mi broþur &punctelev; for me longueth him to seo
For er þane ich him habbe i-sei&yogh;e &punctelev; Ine worþe nou&yogh;t bliþe, i-wis
Min heorte is so muche opon him &punctelev; and no wonder it nis."
¶ "A, sire," quath þe luþere Quiene &punctelev; "&yogh;wane it ne mot oþur beo
Furst ichulle to þe drinke &punctelev; and þu schalt him sethþe i-seo."
I-redi was þe Botiler &punctelev; and brou&yogh;te him drinke a-non
Among þe oþere þat þare weren &punctelev; o schrewe þare cam gon
And wel-comede him with fair semblaunt &punctelev; and made him Ioye i-nov&yogh;
And custe him Iudases cos &punctelev; and sone him þere a-slov&yogh;
For ase he stoupede and custe him &punctelev; redi he was i-nov&yogh;
Þoru&yogh; is wombe he smot a knijf &punctelev; and is gottes al-to-drov&yogh;
Þis holie Man sat upri&yogh;ht &punctelev; and bi-heold is deþes wounde
he ne rod bote wel luyte wei &punctelev; are he feol to grounde
And liet þere is swete lijf— &punctelev; is soule to heouene wende
Alas, luytel vuel þou&yogh;te he &punctelev; þo þe schrewe is wombe rende
Ake he was luþur ase Iudas &punctelev; þat so feolliche him custe
And with tricherie is wombe rende &punctelev; are he it euere wuste
Þo þis holie Man i-martred was &punctelev; huy þat him brou&yogh;ten þer-to
Bi-þou&yogh;ten hou huy mi&yogh;hten best &punctelev; with þis holie bodie do
In-to a dierne stude huy wenden &punctelev; and þar-inne is bodi huy caste
Wel filliche and stilleliche &punctelev; and bureden it þare wel faste
¶ þo þis holie Man i-martred was &punctelev; þe Quiene hadde hire wille;
For li&yogh;htliche Men holdeth euere with þe quike &punctelev; and þe dede is sone stille
Men nomen þo þat child Aþeldred &punctelev; þat was þe Quiene sone
And aftur is broþur mauden him king &punctelev; as ri&yogh;ht was and wone
¶ Þe hei&yogh;e men alle of þe lond &punctelev; with him heolden echon
Ase with heore prince and heore louerd &punctelev; and þene dede for-&yogh;ete a-non
Ake among lowe Men and simple &punctelev; deol þere was i-nou&yogh;
huy corseden alle with-oute god &punctelev; þat heore louerd a-slou&yogh;
"Alas," huy seiden, "&yogh;wat schulle we nouþe? &punctelev; ho schal for us beo
ho schal us nouþe fram weorre wite[MS. us wite]? &punctelev; &yogh;wodere schulle we nouþe fleo
ho schal nou pais in londe holde? &punctelev; ore ioye is al i-do
Of weorre and wo we mouwen beo sikere &punctelev; al wrechhede comethþ us to."
¶ Grete wille hadden þe guode Men &punctelev; of þe contreie bi-side
In sum fair place þat bodi legge &punctelev; and sou&yogh;ten it wel wide;
huy ortreuweden wel þat it were &punctelev; in sum foul stude i-do
huy sou&yogh;ten it ofte wide a-boute &punctelev; and ne couþen nou&yogh;t come þer-to
On a time ase þis guode men &punctelev; of wareygne þare bi-side
In þe contreye wenden and sou&yogh;ten &punctelev; þis holie bodi ful wide
huy stoden and bi-heolden[MS. bi-heoldem] heom bi-side &punctelev; þo isei&yogh;en huy gret li&yogh;ht
And cler with-alle a-boute one place &punctelev; ase apiler stonde upri&yogh;ht
¶ Huy þou&yogh;ten þat þere was godes grace. &punctelev; þudere huy wenden and sou&yogh;te
And founden þere þis holie bodi &punctelev; and up of þe eorþe it brou&yogh;ten
Þare was wop and sor i-nov &punctelev; þo huy sei&yogh;en is grisli wounde
Ake &yogh;eot was heore heorte glad &punctelev; and Ioyful, þo huy him founde
With wel fair procession &punctelev; þis bodi forth huy bere
In-to þe toun of warayne &punctelev; and faire it bureden þere;
In a churche-&yogh;erd of ore leuedi &punctelev; bi este þe churche a luyte
Þare huy bureden þat swete bodi &punctelev; with gret honur and pruyte
A chapele þare is arerd &punctelev; ase þat holie bodi lai
In þe toun of warygne &punctelev; þat stant &yogh;eot to þis dai
Þe put þare he was feorst i-founde &punctelev; a welle þare gan springue
Fair and cler, þat &yogh;eot i-last &punctelev; and is ofte gret botningue
Þat Men cleopieth &yogh;eot to þis day &punctelev; "seint Edwardes welle;"
þare Mani Miracle hath i-beo &punctelev; ase þe contreie dethþ telle
¶ Þat holie bodi lay guode &yogh;wyle &punctelev; þare it was i-do
In þe toune of waraygne &punctelev; and Mani man cam þar-to
Þe tiþingue hov he i-martred was &punctelev; sone sprong wel wide
And þe Miracles þat for him comen &punctelev; a-boute in eche side
An hei&yogh; Eorl þare was a-londe þo &punctelev; þat i-hoten was Alfez
Þat seint Edward louede muche &punctelev; þe &yogh;wyle he liuede her
Þo he heorde of þe Miracles telle &punctelev; þat ore louerd for him wrou&yogh;te
Glad and bliþe he was i-nou&yogh; &punctelev; ase ech Man wel ou&yogh;te;
him þou&yogh;te it was wel vuele i-do &punctelev; þat he lai so lowe þere
Þat he nere i-bured in herre stude &punctelev; ase he wel wuyrþe were;
Gret deol he hadde in is herte &punctelev; þat he was a-morþred so
And swuch a creature ase he was &punctelev; in so lowe stude i-do
In deorsete he wende wide a-boute &punctelev; to þe hei&yogh;e men alle þere
To Bischopes and to Abbodes al-so &punctelev; þat in Enguelonde were
And bad heom of þulke holie bodi &punctelev; þat huy it þannes bere
To herre stude ase it was wuyrþe &punctelev; and þat huy þare-a-&yogh;ein nere
his Messagers he sende a-boute &punctelev; for þis þing wel wide
And to þe Abbesse of wiltone &punctelev; þat i-hote was wilfride
And to Eadithþe þe holie wumman &punctelev; þat Nonne al-so was þar,[orig. þer]
Þat was seint Edwardes suster &punctelev; and þe kingus dou&yogh;ter Edgar
So þat Bischopus and Abbodes &punctelev; and hei&yogh;e Men mani on
To-gadere comen in a time &punctelev; ase huy bi-speken echon
¶ To þis holi bodi huy wenden. &punctelev; and þo huy þer-to come
hol and sound huy founden it ligge &punctelev; þo huy þat bodi up nome
Al-so hol it was with-oute weomme &punctelev; ase it euer er a-liue was
Þare nas nou&yogh;t on þat it i-sei&yogh; &punctelev; þat glad and Ioyful þere-fore nas
Ake Eadithþe, is holie suster &punctelev; to þat bodi orn a-non
And bi-clupte þat bodi and custe it faste &punctelev; bi-fore heom euerechon;
For gladnesse heo lov&yogh; and weop &punctelev; teres wel mani on
Þo heo sai&yogh; hire broþur so a-slawe &punctelev; and so sovnd of flechs and bon
ho-so nadde neuere deol i-sei&yogh;e &punctelev; of hire he mi&yogh;hte þere
Þis hei&yogh;e men with gret honur &punctelev; þat holie bodi forth bere
With gret song and procession. &punctelev; muche folk þuder-ward drov&yogh;
Ore louerd dude þare for is loue &punctelev; fair Miracle i-nov&yogh;
¶ For tweie crupeles þat in heore limes &punctelev; al fur-crokede were
Mid gret hope leien in þe wey &punctelev; and a-biden þe bere
hore limes bi-gunne to rechchen a-ri&yogh;ht &punctelev; and hole bi-comen a-non;
Þare was Ioye and blisse i-nou&yogh; &punctelev; a-mong þis men ech-on
¶ His stepmoder, þat him þare-to brou&yogh;te &punctelev; herof herde telle
hire of-þou&yogh;te, þo he swuch man was &punctelev; þat he[= heo] him let so quelle
Ope hire palefrey heo werth a day &punctelev; aftur þat bodi to wiende
To bidde for-&yogh;iuenesse of hire misdede &punctelev; &yogh;if god hire wolde siende
¶ Ase heo wolde þuder-ward wiende &punctelev; and with hire mani on
huy ne mi&yogh;hten make hire palefrey &punctelev; þat it ane fote wolde gon;
huy schouen it faste forthþe-ward and drowen &punctelev; and neuere þe betere it nas
Þe Quiene þou&yogh;te on hire misdede &punctelev; þat al þare-fore it was
heo a-li&yogh;hte of hire palefrey &punctelev; and wolde a-fote gon
To-ward þat holie cors. &punctelev; ake heo nadde power non;
A-&yogh;ein-ward heo mi&yogh;hte wel gon &punctelev; ake forthþe-ward for no-þing
Heo bi-lefte, þo it was non oþur &punctelev; in gret deol and mournyng
Of hire misdedes heo repentede hire sore &punctelev; ase manie Men habbeth i-sed
And cam to guod mendement &punctelev; are þat heo were ded
¶ Þis Men ladden þis holie bodi &punctelev; with gret honur and pruyte
To þe Abbeye of Schaftesburi &punctelev; þare ase he lijth &yogh;uyte
A-mong blake Nonnene þat þare beoth &punctelev; and al-so þare weren þo
Þat fram þe toun of waraygne &punctelev; is twenti Mile and mo;
In þe northha[l]f of þe hei&yogh;e Autere &punctelev; in þe walle bi-side
huy leiden þis holie bodi &punctelev; þat manie men sechez wide
In-to þulke Abbeie of Schafteburij &punctelev; seint Edward huy ladde
For þe kyng Alfred, is graunt-sire &punctelev; þat hous a-rerd hadde
And made þar-inne is dou&yogh;ter Nonne &punctelev; þat was i-hote al&yogh;yue
For hire loue he hadde þat hous arerd &punctelev; and muche guod þudere in i-&yogh;iue
An hondret hidenene[r. hidene] of guod lond &punctelev; with hire he &yogh;af þer
Þat hous, al-so freo in eche point &punctelev; ase he him-sulf it heold er
In þis Abbeie seint edward &punctelev; lai on and twenti &yogh;er
So þat huy i-seien tokningue ofte &punctelev; þat he nolde nonmore beo þer
For &yogh;wane men comen ofte to is toumbe &punctelev; ase li&yogh;thliche up huy as bere
And heuen as up and doun ase huy wolden &punctelev; ase þei it li&yogh;ht treov were
¶ Seint Edward cam al-so ani&yogh;ht &punctelev; ase in a visioun
To an holi man þat þere was nei&yogh; &punctelev; in an oþur religion;
"Go," he seide, "to Schafteburi &punctelev; to þe Abbesse of þe house
Dame Aldred þat clene Maide &punctelev; þat is godes spouse
And seie hire þat i-nelle nonmore &punctelev; ligge þare ich nou do;
Þat ich beo i-brou&yogh;t in an oþur stude &punctelev; and þat heo segge mi broþer so."
¶ Þis guode Man a-morewe a-ros &punctelev; and ne fur-&yogh;at nou&yogh;t þis cas
To þe Abbesse he wende of Schafteburi &punctelev; and tolde al hou it was
Þis guode womman was glad i-nou&yogh;! &punctelev; to þe kyngue heo wende sone
And of is broþur tolde him al &punctelev; and &yogh;wat þer-of were to done
Welle, þe kyng was one glad &punctelev; þo he i-heorde telle
So swete tiþingue of is broþur &punctelev; þei is moder him liete a-quelle
¶ He wolde habbe i-went to schafteburi &punctelev; In shrine him to bringue
Ac he was so bi-set mid weorre &punctelev; þat he ne mi&yogh;hte for no þingue
For is fon ornen so faste him up-on &punctelev; þat he ne mi&yogh;hte þannes wiende
To heie Men a-boute in þe londe &punctelev; wel sone he gan siende
And to wilfin þe guode bischop &punctelev; þat was bischop þo
Þat huy scholden with gret honour &punctelev; to schafteburie go
And his broþur in schrine bringue &punctelev; ase ri&yogh;th was forto done
¶ Þe Bischop with þis oþur Men &punctelev; to schafteburi comen sone
With swiþe fair procession &punctelev; to is toumbe huy wende
A swiþe fair Miracle a-mong heom alle &punctelev; ore louerd for him þere sende
For a-non so huy openeden þat lid &punctelev; of is swete toumbe þere
Þare cam a-doun þoru&yogh; al þe churche &punctelev; ase þei it a mist were
A-mong al þe prece þat þere was &punctelev; þat huy i-seien alle with ei&yogh;e
Fleu&yogh;[al. flen] a-mon[g] heom al-so a myst— &punctelev; so swote þing neuere huy er ne sei&yogh;e
¶ So swote was þe smul and guod &punctelev; þat alle þat þere were
For muruþe þou&yogh;ten þat huy stoden &punctelev; in parays and nou&yogh;t þere
Þis holi bodi up huy nomen &punctelev; with gret honour and pruyte
And leiden it in a wel fair schrine &punctelev; þare ase it lijth &yogh;uyte
In þis manere he was i-schrined &punctelev; in þe on an twentiþe &yogh;ere
Þat þe hei&yogh;e men him brou&yogh;ten fro waram &punctelev; and bureden him furst þere;
A þousend &yogh;er it was and on &punctelev; after þulke stounde
Þat ore louerd was on eorþe i-bore &punctelev; and a-li&yogh;hte for us to grounde
¶ His broþur, þe king Aþeldred &punctelev; guod man was i-nou&yogh;;
Edward was is sone i-hote &punctelev; þat to alle guodnesse drou&yogh;
Þat king was sethþe aftur him &punctelev; and hei&yogh; halewe in heouene is
I-cleoped seint Edward aftur is vncle &punctelev; at West-Munstre he lijth, i-wis
¶ Op-on Mi&yogh;hel-masse fourtene-ny&yogh;ht &punctelev; his day fallez in þe &yogh;ere
And a-midde þe Monþe of luyde[18 March] &punctelev; seint Edwardes dai þere.[= þe ere]
Nov god for þe loue of heom boþe &punctelev; þet swete kingues were
To þe Ioye of heouene þat huy beoth inne &punctelev; with heom us bringue þere

div1.head: 18 Franceys.[This life is based on the Vita s. Fr. by S. Bonaventura, in Act. SS. Boll. Oct. 4, p. 742 ff.]

lg.l: SEint Fraunceys, þe frere Menour &punctelev; þat guod man was i-nov&yogh;
Marchaunt he was in his &yogh;onghede &punctelev; and to eche treuwenesse drov&yogh;
his Marchaundise he maude a[al. al] day &punctelev; in þe cite of Asise;
And in almesdede he spendede an[om. an] on pouere Men &punctelev; muchedel is Marchaundise;
For no loue of catel &punctelev; he it nolde bi-leue
&YOGH;wane ani pouere man him bede &punctelev; bote he him som-&yogh;wat &yogh;eue
¶ Ase he cam a day bi þe wei &punctelev; he gan mieten bi cas
Ane kni&yogh;t þat hadde Riche i-beo &punctelev; and[MS. and and] swiþe a-pouered was;
vuele he was i-cloþed al-so &punctelev; and bad him sum guod
Seint Fraunceys hadde reuþe of him &punctelev; and one &yogh;wyle he with-stod
¶ he strepte of is cloþes of is rug &punctelev; and &yogh;af þis pouere kny&yogh;t
And þer-aftur ase he lay a-slepe &punctelev; in is bedde a-ny&yogh;t
A swiþe noble paleys &punctelev; him þou&yogh;te þat he i-sei&yogh;;
he Axede was þat paleys were &punctelev; þat so riche was and hei&yogh;;
Men seiden him þat it was his &punctelev; and is kni&yogh;tes al-so
Þo þis holie Man a-wok &punctelev; sum-&yogh;wat he þou&yogh;te do
In þat paleys him þou&yogh;te he sai&yogh; al-so &punctelev; kny&yogh;htes Armes þere
And with afair creoiz þoru&yogh;-out &punctelev; I-markede alle huy were
¶ Þou&yogh;te he, "ore louerd it wole &punctelev; þat ich mi-seolf kny&yogh;t beo
And swyþe feble ich am þare-to &punctelev; bote ich me bet bi-seo."
An Eorl þare was in poile[= Apoile] &punctelev; þat was corteys and hende
he þou&yogh;te kny&yogh;t beo i-maud of him &punctelev; þuder-ward he gan wende
Ase he wende towar[d] þis Eorl &punctelev; for-to beo i-maud kni&yogh;t
Ore swete louerd in Auision &punctelev; to him cam a ni&yogh;th;
"Sei&yogh;e me," he seide, "of þe louerd &punctelev; and of þe hyne al-so
And of þe riche man and of þe pouere &punctelev; &yogh;wuch may þe mest guod do?"
"Bote þe louerd," quath þis oþur &punctelev; "and he þat is riche."
"Þou haddest almest i-chose," ore louerd seide &punctelev; "þat ful oni-liche
For truste of þe hyne &punctelev; þene louerd þou for-soke;
Þov nome vuele þin Avision &punctelev; þou most þe bet bi-loke
¶ Þe Armure and þe paleis &punctelev; þat þou so noble i-sei&yogh;e
Elles-&yogh;ware þov schalt finde &punctelev; Ake þou ne comest nou&yogh;t &yogh;uit so hei&yogh;e;
Kny&yogh;tes þov schalt habbe onder þe &punctelev; þulke Armes for-to lede
Þare-fore wend þe hom a-&yogh;ein &punctelev; and bi-þench bet þi dede!"
¶ Þis holi man, þo he a-wok &punctelev; a-&yogh;ein wende to Asise
And þou&yogh;te al on Ihesu crist &punctelev; and bi-lefde is Marchaundise
And bad ore louerd ny&yogh;ht and dai &punctelev; þat he scholde him rede
And some tokningue senden him &punctelev; hov he scholde is lijf lede
¶ A day, ase þis holie man &punctelev; with-oute Asise him drou&yogh;
he mette a lodlich Mesel &punctelev; þat revlich was i-nou&yogh;
And bad him sum guod for godes loue. &punctelev; seint Fraunceys a-li&yogh;hte
And bi-clupte and custe þane sike man &punctelev; ase faire ase he mi&yogh;hte
And of is seluer him tok &punctelev; and bad him habbe guod day
Þo nuste he &yogh;ware he was bi-come &punctelev; ne in none stude him ne say
¶ Þo þou&yogh;te wel ho it was &punctelev; and aftur þulke dede
he wep and cride on ihesu crist &punctelev; þat he scholde him sum-&yogh;wat rede;
And ofte he wolde bi costome &punctelev; to Meseles fare
And sechen heom at heore owene hous &punctelev; bote he founde hem elles|&yogh;ware
And cusse heore hondene and heore fet &punctelev; and heore Mouth al-s[o]
And &yogh;yue heom guod wel largeliche— &punctelev; bi costome he wolde it do.[a later hand adds als]
¶ Bi a churche of seint Damian &punctelev; a day he cam gon
Þat ope þe poynte was to falle a-doun. &punctelev; In he wende a-non
And kneolede a-doun bi-fore þe croiz &punctelev; ase he dude wel ofte
Þo spac a voiz þare-inne &punctelev; wel Mildeliche and softe
And seide, "Fraunceys, go þe forth &punctelev; and a-rer up min hous an hei&yogh;
Þat, þou sixt, fallez to grounde &punctelev; and al destruyd is nei&yogh;."
¶ Seint Fraunceys, for þe churche was &punctelev; a-done-ward al i-brou&yogh;t
Wende þat ore louer[d] þare-bi seide— &punctelev; ake þar-of nas it nou&yogh;t
he wende and solde is cloþes a-non &punctelev; and muche of is oþur þingue
And þe panes þat he nam þare-with &punctelev; to þis church gan bringue
Þe pr[e]ost of þe churche he fond þere &punctelev; þe panes he wolde him take
To arere up þe pouere churche. &punctelev; and he heom gan for-sake;
he ne dorste nou&yogh;t for is fader &punctelev; ne for is oþur freond, he seide
So muche tresor nime of him &punctelev; bote it were bi heore rede
¶ Seint Fraunceys nam þat tresor &punctelev; þo þe oþur it for-sok
And in a fenestre leide it þere &punctelev; and in ore louerdes warde it tok
Þo þe tyþingue cam to is fader &punctelev; þat he hadde i-sold is guod
Toward him he wende anon &punctelev; and for wrath was nei&yogh; wod
Seint Frau[n]ceys was i-war of him &punctelev; and ne bi-lefte nou&yogh;t bi-hinde
he wende and hudde him in a Dich &punctelev; þat he ne mi&yogh;hte him nou&yogh;t finde
In þis Diche wel longue he lay &punctelev; in hunguer and wrech-hede
And euere cride on Ihesu crist &punctelev; þat he scholde him betere rede
¶ So longue he was þare in meseise &punctelev; þat he for-ferde nei&yogh;
Þat vnneþe him couþe i-knowe &punctelev; ani man þat him sei&yogh;
Atþe laste in meseise i-nov&yogh; &punctelev; he wende to Asise
Þat folk, þo huy seien him com[e] &punctelev; heom gan ful sore a-grise
And seiden "here cometh a wod Man" &punctelev; huy harleden him wel faste
And smiten and pulten here and þere &punctelev; and dunge on him caste
Seint Fraunceis wende euere forth &punctelev; ase þei him no-þing nere
¶ his fader cam al-so bi cas &punctelev; and i-mette him þere
he ladde him hom to is hous &punctelev; and beot him sore i-nov&yogh;
And bad him bringue hom þat catel &punctelev; þat he er a-wei drov&yogh;
Þo he ne mi&yogh;hte habbe non oþur word &punctelev; he bond him swiþe strongue;
